meta.title: Everland - Trust & Safety Reporting System
meta.subtitle: Designing a player-first reporting flow for a fictional MMO

project.summary:
Role: Lead Narrative Designer

Company: Everland MMO

Timeline: 1 Year

Tools & Collaborators: Figma, Google Workspace, Product Managers, UI/UX Designers, Engineers

This case study showcases the redesign of Everland's trust and safety reporting system. The project focused on creating an intuitive, multi-entry-point flow that helps players quickly report harmful behavior while setting clear expectations about outcomes. The work included in-game UI copy, user flow design, and enforcement communication templates.

section.heading: The Problem
section.body:
Everland's existing reporting system was underutilized and created confusion for players who encountered harmful behavior. Key issues included:

  • Limited access points: Players could only report from one location in the game
  • Unclear outputs: The system didn't communicate what would happen after a report was filed
  • Poor information architecture: Report categories were confusing and didn't match player mental models
  • Lack of agency: Players had no immediate tools to protect themselves while waiting for moderation action

This resulted in low report submission rates and increased player frustration with the community safety experience.

section.heading: Goals
section.body:
1. Create multiple entry points so players can report from anywhere they encounter problems
  2. Make reporting fast with streamlined flows that don't interrupt gameplay unnecessarily
  3. Improve information architecture with clear, intuitive report categories
  4. Set clear expectations about what happens after submission
  5. Suggest immediate safety controls players can use while waiting for moderation

section.heading: User Flow
section.body:
I designed a flexible flow with four entry points that all lead to the same streamlined three-screen process:

Entry Points

  • Profile dropdown: From any player's profile card
  • Chat message dropdown: Directly from a message in chat
  • Waypoint menu: From the main game menu
  • Settings: From the Settings > Help & Support section

Three-Screen Process

  1. Select a reason: Choose from clear, user-friendly categories
  2. Add details: Provide context with optional text and evidence
  3. Confirmation: Get immediate feedback and suggested safety actions

This approach ensures players can report from their natural context without having to remember where the reporting tool lives or navigate through multiple menus.

section.heading: Screen 1: Select a Reason
section.body:
The first screen presents clear, plain-language categories that match how players think about problems, not how the moderation team categorizes them internally.

Copy

Header: Report Player

Subheader: Why are you reporting [Player Name]?

Categories:

  • Harassment or hate speech
    This player used slurs, threatened me, or targeted me repeatedly
  • Spam or advertising
    This player posted repetitive messages or advertised external services
  • Cheating or exploits
    This player used hacks, bots, or took advantage of game exploits
  • Inappropriate name or content
    This player's username, profile, or shared content violates our guidelines
  • Scamming or fraud
    This player tried to trick me or steal from me
  • Other
    Something else that doesn't fit these categories

Button: Next

Design Decisions

  • Player-centric language: Categories use "This player..." to maintain focus on the action being reported
  • Descriptive subtext: Each category includes examples so players can make confident choices
  • Flat hierarchy: All options at one level—no nested menus or complex decision trees

section.heading: Screen 2: Add Details
section.body:
The second screen collects context while keeping the burden low. All fields are optional to prevent report abandonment.

Copy

Header: Add Details (Optional)

Body text: Help us understand what happened. The more details you provide, the faster we can review your report.

Text field label: What happened?

Text field placeholder: Describe what this player did...

Character limit: 500 characters

Evidence section label: Evidence (Optional)

Evidence helper text: Screenshots, chat logs, or other evidence can help our team review faster.

Button: Attach File

Accepted formats note: Accepted formats: .png, .jpg, .txt (Max 5MB)

Buttons:

  • Back (secondary)
  • Submit Report (primary)

Design Decisions

  • Everything is optional: Players can submit with just a category selection if they prefer
  • Encouraging but not demanding: Copy explains why details help without making them feel required
  • Clear file restrictions: Prevents errors and sets expectations about what can be attached

section.heading: Screen 3: Confirmation
section.body:
The final screen confirms submission, sets expectations about timing, and—critically—suggests immediate actions players can take to protect themselves.

Copy

Header: Report Submitted

Icon: ✓ (checkmark)

Body text: Thanks for helping keep Everland safe. Our Trust & Safety team will review your report within 24 hours.

Subheader: Take Action Now

Suggested actions:

  • Block [Player Name]
    They won't be able to message you or see your profile
  • Mute [Player Name]
    You won't see their messages in chat, but they can still see yours
  • Leave this area
    Fast-travel to a different zone to avoid further interaction

Note: These actions are immediate and don't require moderator approval.

Button: Return to Game

Design Decisions

  • Immediate reassurance: Visual checkmark and thank-you message confirm the action was successful
  • Clear timeline: "Within 24 hours" sets realistic expectations without overpromising
  • Empowerment: Suggested actions give players agency instead of leaving them feeling helpless
  • Explaining each action: Brief descriptions help players understand what each option does
  • Emphasis on immediacy: Note clarifies these are instant tools, not more waiting

section.heading: Enforcement Communications
section.body:
In addition to the reporting flow, I created templated email communications for the three most common enforcement actions. These emails needed to be clear, firm, and consistent while maintaining Everland's friendly tone.

Email 1: Chat Restriction

Subject: Action Taken on Your Everland Account

Body:

Hi [Player Name],

We're reaching out because your chat privileges in Everland have been temporarily restricted.

What happened:
Our Trust & Safety team reviewed reports about messages you sent and determined they violated our Community Guidelines, specifically our rules around [SPECIFIC VIOLATION, e.g., "harassment and abusive language"].

What this means:
For the next [DURATION, e.g., "48 hours"], you won't be able to send messages in public chat, private messages, or guild chat. You can still play the game normally, join groups, and participate in activities.

Next steps:
Your chat privileges will be automatically restored on [DATE/TIME]. To avoid future restrictions, please review our Community Guidelines: [LINK]

If you believe this restriction was applied in error, you can appeal by replying to this email with additional context.

Thanks for helping us keep Everland a welcoming place for everyone.

— The Everland Trust & Safety Team

Email 2: Temporary Suspension

Subject: Your Everland Account Has Been Suspended

Body:

Hi [Player Name],

Your Everland account has been temporarily suspended due to a violation of our Community Guidelines.

What happened:
Our Trust & Safety team investigated reports about your behavior and determined you violated our rules around [SPECIFIC VIOLATION, e.g., "cheating and use of unauthorized third-party software"]. This is a serious violation that negatively impacts other players' experiences.

What this means:
Your account is suspended for [DURATION, e.g., "7 days"]. You won't be able to log in or access any part of Everland during this time.

Next steps:
Your suspension will be lifted on [DATE/TIME]. Before returning, please review our Community Guidelines: [LINK]

Important: Future violations may result in a permanent ban from Everland.

If you believe this suspension was applied in error, you can appeal by replying to this email with additional context within 7 days.

— The Everland Trust & Safety Team

Email 3: Indefinite Suspension (Ban)

Subject: Your Everland Account Has Been Permanently Suspended

Body:

Hi [Player Name],

Your Everland account has been permanently suspended and you will no longer be able to access the game.

What happened:
After reviewing reports and your account history, our Trust & Safety team determined you engaged in severe or repeated violations of our Community Guidelines, specifically [SPECIFIC VIOLATION, e.g., "repeated harassment and hate speech targeting other players"].

What this means:
Your account is permanently banned. You will not be able to log in, and any purchased content or progress cannot be transferred or refunded. Creating new accounts to bypass this ban is also against our Terms of Service and will result in those accounts being banned as well.

Next steps:
This decision is final in most cases. However, if you believe this suspension was applied in error, you may submit an appeal by replying to this email within 14 days with:

  • A detailed explanation of why you believe the ban was incorrect
  • Any evidence or context that wasn't previously available to our team

Appeals are reviewed carefully, but please note that permanent bans are only issued after thorough investigation.

— The Everland Trust & Safety Team

Design Decisions for Enforcement Emails

  • Consistent structure: All emails follow the same "What happened / What this means / Next steps" format for scanability
  • Specific but not inflammatory: Copy references the violation type without quoting offensive content
  • Clear consequences: Each email explicitly states what the player can and cannot do
  • Path forward: All enforcement actions include either automatic restoration or appeal instructions
  • Escalation language: Severity increases from chat restriction to temporary suspension to permanent ban
  • Firm but respectful tone: Copy maintains professionalism without being punitive or emotional

section.heading: Key Takeaways
section.body:
• Meet users where they are: Multiple entry points dramatically increased accessibility—players didn't have to "go find" the reporting tool
  • Optional doesn't mean useless: Making details optional reduced abandonment while still collecting valuable context from motivated reporters
  • Immediate agency matters: Suggesting self-service safety controls reduced follow-up contacts and player frustration
  • Enforcement needs empathy too: Even when delivering bad news, clear structure and respectful tone maintained player trust in the moderation system
  • Content design shapes behavior: The way we present options influences which tools players use and how they think about community safety

outcomes.outcome: Created a flexible, multi-entry-point reporting system accessible from anywhere in the game
Designed three-screen flow that balanced thoroughness with ease of use
Developed templated enforcement communications maintaining consistency and professionalism
Empowered players with immediate safety controls while waiting for moderation review
